Award.AwardTitle: I-Math: An Interdisciplinary Math Training Platform
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop an interdisciplinary math (I-Math) program that integrates education and research for mathematics majors and trains the next generation of applied mathematicians, furnishing students with a strong interdisciplinary background. This program provides a new platform to promote undergraduate mathematics training through an interdisciplinary collaboration, establishing the infrastructure that accommodates a large number of students and spans most years of their college careers. Students will gain knowledge, problem-solving skills, hands-on experience, and rigorous research training through the proposed program. The success of this project will provide a potentially transformative model for large-scale interdisciplinary mathematics education and research training that can be widely adapted and implemented in regional and national higher educational institutions.

The I-Math program involves four core areas: biological math, computer math, data math, and engineering math, to accommodate a broad range of student interests. Each core represents a partnership between Mathematics and another department, with a matched pair of faculty members to lead the training efforts. The faculty members on this team have extensive experience in interdisciplinary research and education, and they will incorporate their expertise and research findings into the development of innovative curricula and research projects. The training efforts will be centered on student engagement, stimulating student interest, and improving persistence and academic competence, to prepare knowledgeable and responsible 21st-century applied mathematicians.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop an educational program for interdisciplinary mathematics (I-Math) at the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga (UTC). The project trains math majors toward the next generation of applied mathematicians with a strong interdisciplinary background. Through this project, a multidisciplinary team is assembled that consists of faculty members from mathematics, statistics, biology, engineering and computer science, and a pilot platform is established for interdisciplinary education and training of college students.

The I-Math program involves four core areas: biological math, computer math, data math, and engineering math, to accommodate a broad range of student interests. Each core represents a partnership between mathematics and another discipline, with a matched pair of faculty members to lead the training activities. A focus of this project is the development of innovative and independent course modules related to upper-level mathematics and its various applications to biology, computer science, data science, and engineering. These short course modules are flexible and portable, and they have been incorporated into a number of lower-level college math courses targeting freshmen and sophomores. This curricular endeavor provides an exposure of advanced mathematical concepts and their many exciting applications to students at an early stage of their college experience. Through this effort, the project aims to promote the application of mathematics, stimulate the interest of students, and improve the retention and academic competence of students in mathematics as well as other STEM fields. There are also a number of learning activities designed to engage students outside the classroom. For example, an interdisciplinary math seminar has been established in this program. The seminar series provides a forum for faculty and students to share new findings in applied mathematics and its interdisciplinary applications, at a level accessible to undergraduate math majors.

In addition, the math training efforts at UTC have been integrated with outreach activities for the community outside the University. Particularly, an Interdisciplinary Mathematics Summer Camp for high school students has been organized on UTC campus four year in a row. Each summer camp is for one week and it has attracted students from the Chattanooga area and other parts of Tennessee, as well as neighboring states such as Georgia and Alabama. High school students attending the camp have enjoyed the learning experience from the daily lectures, interactive labs, group projects, and many hands-on activities, and from the direct interaction with university professors in multiple disciplines.

Overall, the I-Math program creates a unique math education and training platform for college students and the STEM community at large. Through the learning activities developed in this project, students gain mathematical knowledge, computational techniques, hands-on experiences and complex problem solving skills, and build up a strong interdisciplinary background. All of these improve the quality of their education and benefit their professional development in the future.
